How is that they failed to cover the $1 outscourced for production is lost forever?
You send $10 to China to make your product that is sent back to US for sale. That $10 is never returned to US because that Chinese worker isn't going to fly to US to spend it. This creates a deficit.
The company just looks at is as the cost of manufacturing. But in terms of the value of USD, it is devalued.

Small towns are perfect examples. A Casion employs 100s of people. Out of town tourist bring money into the Casino. The Casino pays its employees with that money. Employees spend it in town. Town collects the taxes and spends it within the town. As tourism grows, the town grows and vice versa. If the Casino were to bus in workers from out of town because it's cheaper, the town has no growth at all. Even if Tourism to the Casino were to grow exponentially.

The problem is that macroeconomic theories are based on assertions inconsistent with the way the world is actually organized. Economic outcomes are dictated by politics, by systems of law and taxation. Economics is a discipline that grew in influence by being funded by individuals who had a very strong vested interest in defense of the status quo. This story is detailed in a book co-authored in 1994 by an economics professor named Mason Gaffney, titled "The Corruption of Economics." Anyone considering formal study of economics should first read this book.

9:39 The idea that Inflation = growth, and Deflation = recession is erroneous. Just think about it for a second. If the supply of money is stable, growth is deflationary as there are more goods and services per monetary unit. In the 1870's and '80s the US had robust growth and falling prices. Also, the fear that people might not send all their money is totally wrong headed. Economic growth depends on robust savings and investments. So when prices are gently falling due to growth, people will save more, leading to more growth. However, inflation discourages savings and hurts growth. Consider the stagflation of the '70s, for example... not to mention any hyperinflation in history you'd care to look at. Deflation is only a problem when it's caused by a sharp decrease in the supply of money.

This is a Keynesian view that stems from the idea that there needs to be spending to keep an economy moving and stop the cycle of falling demand.The reality is though that the reason there is no demand and prices need to fall in order for people to afford them. Yes it's bad or the economy in the short run, but it is a necessary correction for the long run, because the production does not justify the consumption. They never consider the nature of wealth and the fact that savings drives the economy. Only people who save can build wealth there is a difference between real market driven demand from savings that sets prices, and propped up prices that keep people spending from some other propped up source. Those price signals they referred to earlier also get totally skewed and it creates great distortion for investors.

Main outtakes of this lesson
1) Macroeconomics - the study of the entire economy as a whole rather than individual markets.
2) In general policy makers try to achieve three goals:
a. Keep the economy growing over time (gross domestic product - GDP)
b. Limit unemployment (unemployment rate)
c. Keep prices stable (inflation rate)
3) GDP is the value of all final goods and services produced within a country's border in a specific period of time, usually a year.
a. Transactions where nothing new was produced - don't count as GDP.
b. Also not including illegal activities.
c. Measured in dollars.
d. Nominal GDP is GDP not adjusted for inflation.
e. Real GDP is GDP adjusted for inflation.
4) Recession - when two successful quarters, or six months, show a decrease in real GDP.
a. Depression - a severe recession.
5) Unemployment rate is calculated by taking the number of people that are unemployed and dividing by the number of people in the labor force, times 100.
a. Discouraged workers - unemployed people that were looking for work, but have given up.
b. There are three types of unemployment:
- frictional unemployment - the time period between jobs, when a worker is searching for, or transitioning from one job to another.
- structural unemployment - unemployment caused by lack of demand for a worker's specific type of labor.
- cyclical unemployment - unemployment due to recession.
c. Natural rate of unemployment - the lowest rate of unemployment that economy can sustain over a long period.
6) Inflation - an increase in a currency supply relative to the number of people using it, resulting in rising prices of goods and services over time.
a. Deflation - a decrease in general price level of goods and services.

The idea that deflation is bad because it discourages spending is incredibly illogical.
A. The price of something (money included) INCLUDES speculation on the value of that thing. If people think the value / buying-power of money will increase, the price will already be larger to account for that. Thus the utility of money should be entirely reflected in what you can buy with your money unless everyone's wrong (usually because the buying power of your money is unstable, which isn't necessarily the case with either deflation or inflation).
B. What you're essentially saying there is that we (the inflators) are going to take a little bit of your money all the time unless you spend it, and thus increase consumer spending. Its essentially blackmail. Is it ok to purposely decrease the value of people's money (really steal that value) to encourage them to spend it on things they otherwise wouldn't? I don't think it is.

In short, calling deflation bad is idiotic. Its very discouraging that economics still spew that kind of evidence-less claims based on theories absolutely riddled with holes.

Quite a few flaws here government spending does not necessarily mean increased debt in fact it is completely unnecessary for it to unlike business and consumer spending where it may be necessary. So it is the least likely to create debt. Also you are assuming governments actually want to reduce unemployment which they don't as it creates inflation. They also want to inflict pressure and workers and reduce the effectiveness of unions. Full unemployment means that workers are in a much better negotiating position. Another point is that you're accepting as fact that economies have to go through boom and bust in a business cycle which is not true.

Another problem with GDP is that it doesn't necessarily reflect values. If a mom decides to stay home with her child instead of working, there's no increase to GDP. If she works 80 hours a week and her kids are raised by nannies, the GDP is increased by both the mother's output and the nanny's. Of course, the kids never see their mom. If one of those kids gets cancer, it's a huge boost to GDP as the kid has to undergo tons of expensive medical procedures. Of course, the GDP increase is at the expense of a kid with cancer.

On the flip side, the GDP does NOT measure "externalities." So if, for example, a factory is able to produce 50% more widgets by dumping toxic chemicals into a pristine lake, the GDP goes up with the increased production. The polluted lake has no downward effect on the GDP. An untouched rainforest produces no GDP except perhaps as a research tool or with tourism. A forest that is clearcut and paved over produces lots of GDP. Clear-cutting a rainforest is great from a GDP perspective, but not so much from pretty much every other perspective.

So even though GDP is a key economics indicator, there are some organizations that are pushing for alternative indicators to take a more prominent place.

Insisting that the topic is exciting simply distracts from the fact that this topic is, indeed, interesting. I know you guys have probably already produced and filmed many of the episodes already, but you don't need to convince me to watch, because I genuinely want to learn.

Deflation is a bad thing because it will stop people form buying? What bs is that? If there is a known pattern such as sales then yes people wont buy until the sales happen, but otherwise most consumers arent going to spent every minute of every day watching for the decrease in price. Peoples thoughts tend to be this priority when buying:

1) Is it on sale in any way?
2) If not on sale, is it in my price range?
3) If too pricey, how much do I want it?

Many do wait for sales indeed and technically this is temporary deflation of particular goods or services to stimulate demands, but the way it was described in the video sounded like the theory believes that the average consumer is speculating constantly.

"Oh a small, non-sale related fall in price? Probs will be cheaper soon." No, people will go "yey a drop in price! Its actually falling back into my spending range rather than having stupid real inflation rates like there has been in the past 15 years!"

That being said, perhaps we would see the effects of deflation more if the current economy wasnt overinflated to shit, well above the average household wage. Right now we desperately need deflation, its only bad if it drops below the increase of average income per capita.
